summary: An internal FBI email chain discussing a backlog in processing digital forensic evidence (CART - Computer Analysis and Response Team) related to the Epstein case and another high-priority matter. The email notes that the assigned analyst is only in the office 1-2 days a week, causing delays.

events.title: FBI email on evidence processing backlog
events.description: Internal FBI email correspondence discussing a backlog in the Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) processing digital evidence, warrant returns, subpoena returns, and prison calls for the Epstein case and another high-priority matter.

keyFacts: The FBI was experiencing a backlog in processing digital forensic evidence for the Epstein case as of April 2020.
The Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) analyst assigned to the Epstein case was only in the office 1-2 days per week, contributing to delays.
The Epstein case was described as a 'high priority matter with a mountain of forensic evidence to process.'
The evidence backlog included digital evidence, warrant returns, subpoena returns, and prison calls.
The email indicates ongoing investigative activity in the Epstein case in April 2020, following Epstein's death in August 2019.
